unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: A New Confidence Interval
question_text:
A reporter surveyed $100$ randomly selected adult women and asked them how much they spend on clothes every year, then constructed a $90\%$ confidence interval based off the data.
If the reporter instead asked $1{,}000$ randomly selected women the same question, the new $90\%$ confidence interval

choices.text: Would be centered higher than the confidence interval constructed of only $100\text{ subjects}$.
Would have a smaller margin of error, but only if the confidence is increased.
Would have a smaller margin of error since larger samples have less variability.
Would have a greater margin of error since there would be a larger variety of opinions.

solution:
If all things remain equal, larger samples would be less variable, thus reducing the margin of error. Therefore, since the sample increased from $100$ to $1{,}000\text{ subjects}$, the margin of error will decrease.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. The center of a confidence interval is based off of the point estimator; in this case, the point estimator is the sample mean. Since the sample mean remains unchanged, the interval will not be centered any higher or lower.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Increasing confidence actually increases the margin of error. Larger confidence means the interval must catch the unknown parameter a higher percentage of the time. To compensate for this, the margin of error would have to be larger resulting in a wider interval.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Larger samples always decrease variability, if all other things remain unchanged.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. The sample increased greatly; the new sample is $10$ times larger than the old sample. Therefore, the margin of error would decrease substantially.
